dialogues.speaker: EXT. VARIOUS DAYS
dialogues.text: 'She' plays through the credits. Exquisite footage of Anna Scott -- the great movie star o time -- an ideal -- the perfect star and woman -- her lif glamour and sophistication and mystery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mix through to William, 35, relaxed, pleasant, informal. follow him as he walks down Portobello Road, carrying a l bread.  It is spring.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Of course, I've seen her films and always thought she was, well, fabulous -- but, you know, million miles from the world I live in.  Which is here -- Notting Hill -- not a bad place to be...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a full fruit market day.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There's the market on weekdays, selling every fruit and vegetable known to man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man in denims exits the tattoo studio.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The tattoo parlour -- with a guy outside who got drunk and now can't remember why he chose 'I Love Ken'...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The racial hair-dressers where everyone comes out looking like the Cookie Monster, whether they like it or not... Sure enough, a girl exits with a huge threaded blue bouff

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then suddenly it's the weekend, and from break of day, hundreds of stalls appears out of nowhere, filling Portobello Road right up to Notting Hill Gate... A frantic crowded Portobello market.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... and thousands of people buy millions of antiques, some genuine... The camera finally settles on a stall selling beautiful s glass windows of various sizes, some featuring biblical s and saints.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... and some not so genuine.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And what's great is that lots of friends have ended up in this part of London -- that's Tony, architect turned chef, who recently invested all the money he ever earned in a new restaurant... Shot of Tony proudly setting out a board outside his rest the sign still being painted.  He receives and approves a fresh salmon.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So this is where I spend my days and years -- in this small village in the middle of a city -- in a house with a blue door that my wife and I bought together... before she left me for a man who looked like Harrison Ford, only even handsomer... We arrive outside his blue-doored house just off Portobel

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... and where I now lead a strange half-life with a lodger called...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Spike! The house has far too many things in it.  Definitely two- bachelor flat. Spike appears.  An unusual looking fellow.  He has unusua hair, unusual facial hair and an unusual Welsh accent: ve white, as though his flesh has never seen the sun.  He we only shorts.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Even he.  Hey, you couldn't help me with an incredibly important decision, could you?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: This is important in comparison to, let's say, whether they should cancel third world debt?

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: That's right -- I'm at last going out on a date with the great Janine and I just want to be sure I've picked the right t-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What are the choices?

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Well... wait for it... (He pulls on a t-shirt) First there's this one... The t-shirt is white with a horrible looking plastic alie coming out of it, jaws open, blood everywhere.  It says ' Blood.'

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yes -- might make it hard to strike a really romantic note.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Point taken. He heads back up the stairs... talks as he changes...

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: I suspect you'll prefer the next one. And he re-enters in a white t-shirt, with a large arrow, pointing down to his flies, saying, 'Get It Here.'

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Cool, huh?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yes -- she might think you don't have true love on your mind.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Wouldn't want that... (and back up he goes) Okay -- just one more. He comes down wearing it.  Lots of hearts, saying, 'You'r most beautiful woman in the world.'

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, yes, that's perfect. Well done.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Thanks.  Great.  Wish me luck.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Good luck. Spike turns and walks upstairs proudly.  Revealing that o back of the t-shirt, also printed in big letters, is writ 'Fancy a fuck?'

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And so it was just another hopeless Wednesday, as I set off through the market to work, little suspecting that this was the day which would change my life forever.  This is work, by the way, my little travel book shop... A small unpretentious store... named 'The Travel Book Co.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... which, well, sells travel books -- and, to be frank with you, doesn't always sell many of those. William enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a small shop, slightly chaotic, bookshelves everywh with little secret bits round corners with even more book Martin, William's sole employee, is waiting enthusiastica He is very keen, an uncrushable optimist.  Perhaps withou cause.  A few seconds later, William stands gloomily behi desk.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Classic.  Absolutely classic. Profit from major sales push -- minus $B!r(J347.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Shall I go get a cappuccino?  Ease the pain.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yes, better get me a half.  All I can afford.

dialogues.speaker: MARIN
dialogues.text: I get your logic.  Demi-capu coming up. He salutes and bolts out the door -- as he does, a woman We only just glimpse her. Cut to William working.  He looks up casually.  And sees something.  His reaction is hard to read.  After a pause.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Can I help you? It is Anna Scott, the biggest movie star in the world -- in his shop.  The most divine, subtle, beautiful woman on When she speaks she is very self-assured and self-contain

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No, thanks.  I'll just look around.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Fine. She wanders over to a shelf as he watches her -- and pick quite smart coffee table book.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: That book's really not good -- just in case, you know, browsing turned to buying.  You'd be wasting your money.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yes.  This one though is... very good. He picks up a book on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I think the man who wrote it has actually been to Turkey, which helps. There's also a very amusing incident with a kebab.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Thanks.  I'll think about it. William suddenly spies something odd on the small TV moni beside him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: If you could just give me a second. Her eyes follow him as he moves toward the back of the sh approaches a man in slightly ill-fitting clothes.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: THIEF
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Bad news.

dialogues.speaker: THIEF
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: We've got a security camera in this bit of the shop.

dialogues.speaker: THIEF
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: So, I saw you put that book down your trousers.

dialogues.speaker: THIEF
dialogues.text: What book?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: The one down your trousers.

dialogues.speaker: THIEF
dialogues.text: I haven't got a book down my trousers.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Right -- well, then we have something of an impasse.  I tell you what -- I'll call the police -- and,  what can I say? -- If I'm wrong about the whole book-down-the-trousers scenario, I really apologize.

dialogues.speaker: THIEF
dialogues.text: Okay -- what if I did have a book down my trousers?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, ideally, when I went back to the desk, you'd remove the Cadogan guide to Bali from your trousers, and either wipe it and put it back, or buy it.  See you in a sec. He returns to his desk.  In the monitor we just glimpse, William, the book coming out of the trousers and put back shelves.  The thief drifts out towards the door.  Anna, w observed all this, is looking at a blue book on the count

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Sorry about that...

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No, that's fine.  I was going to steal one myself but now I've changed my mind.  Signed by the author, I see.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yes, we couldn't stop him.  If you can find an unsigned copy, it's worth an absolute fortune. She smiles.  Suddenly the thief is there.

dialogues.speaker: THIEF
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: THIEF
dialogues.text: Can I have your autograph?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: THIEF
dialogues.text: Rufus. She signs his scruffy piece of paper.  He tries to read i

dialogues.speaker: THIEF
dialogues.text: What does it say?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Well, that's the signature -- and above, it says 'Dear Rufus -- you belong in jail.'

dialogues.speaker: THIEF
dialogues.text: Nice one.  Would you like my phone number?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Tempting but... no, thank you. Thief leaves.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I think I will try this one. She hands William a $B!r(J20 note and the book he said He talks as he handles the transaction.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh -- right -- on second thoughts maybe it wasn't that bad.  Actually -- it's a sort of masterpiece really. None of those childish kebab stories you get in so many travel books these days.  And I'll throw in one of these for free. He drops in one of the signed books.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Very useful for lighting fires, wrapping fish, that sort of things. She looks at him with a slight smile.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Thanks. And leaves.  She's out of his life forever.  William is a dazed.  Seconds later Martin comes back in.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Cappuccino as ordered.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Thanks.  I don't think you'll believe who was just in here.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Who?  Someone famous? But William's innate natural English discretion takes ove

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No. No-one -- no-one. They set about drinking their coffees.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Would be exciting if someone famous did come into the shop though, wouldn't it?  Do you know -- this is pretty incredible actually -- I once saw Ringo Starr.  Or at least I think it was Ringo.  It might have been that broke from 'Fiddler On The Roof,' Toppy.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Topol.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: That's right -- Topol.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: But Ringo Starr doesn't look anything like Topol.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No, well... he was quite a long way away.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: So it could have been neither of them?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I suppose so.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Right.  It's not a classic anecdotes, is it?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Not classic, no. Martin shakes his head.  William drains his cappuccino.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Right -- want another one?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes.  No, wait -- let's go crazy -- I'll have an orange juice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William sets off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William collects his juice in a coffee shop on Westbourne Road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William swings out of the little shop -- he turns the cor Portobello Road and bumps straight into Anna.  The orange juice,  in its foam cup, flies.  It soaks Anna.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Here, let me help. He grabs some paper napkins and starts to clean it off -- far too near her breasts in the panic of it...

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What are you doing?! He jumps back.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Nothing, nothing... Look, I live just over the street -- you could get cleaned up.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No thank you.  I need to get my car back.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I also have a phone.  I'm confident that in five minutes we can have you spick and span and back on the street again... in the non-prostitute sense obviously. In his diffident way, he is confident, despite her being genuinely annoyed.  She turns and looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Okay.  So what does 'just over the street' mean -- give it to me in yards.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Eighteen yards.  That's my house there. He doesn't lie -- it is eighteen yards away.  She looks d She looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter.  She carries a few stylish bags.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Come on in.  I'll just... William runs in further -- it's a mess.  He kicks some ol under the stairs, bins an unfinished pizza and hides a pl breakfast in a cupboard.  She enters the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It's not that tidy, I fear. And he guides her up the stairs, after taking the bag of from her...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: The bathroom is right at the top of the stairs and there's a phone on the desk up there. She heads upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William is tidying up frantically.  Then he hears Anna's the stairs.  She walks down, wearing a short, sparkling b top beneath her leather jacket.  With her trainers still is dazzled by the sight of her.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Would you like a cup of tea before you go?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Orange juice -- probably not. He moves to his very empty fridge -- and offers its only

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Something else cold -- coke, water, some disgusting sugary drink pretending to have something to do with fruits of the forest?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Really, no.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Would you like something to nibble -- apricots, soaked in honey -- quite why, no one knows -- because it stops them tasting of apricots, and makes them taste like honey, and if you wanted honey, you'd just buy honey, instead of apricots, but nevertheless -- there we go -- yours if you want them.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Do you always say 'no' to everything? Pause.  She looks at him deep.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No. (pause) I better be going.  Thanks for your help.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You're welcome and, may I also say... heavenly. It has taken a lot to get this out loud.  He is not a smo talking man.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Take my one chance to say it.  After you've read that terrible book, you're certainly not going to be coming back to the shop. She smiles.  She's cool.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yes.  Well.  My pleasure. He guides her towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you.  Surreal but nice. In a slightly awkward moment, he shows her out the door. closes the door and shakes his head in wonder.  Then...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: 'Surreal but nice.'  What was I thinking? ... He  shakes his head again in horror and wanders back the corridor in silence.  There's a knock on the door.  H back, casually...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Coming. He opens the door.  It's her.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh hi.  Forget something?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I forgot my bag.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh right. He shoots into the kitchen and picks up the forgotten sho bag.  Then returns and hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Thanks.  Well... They stand in that corridor -- in that small space.  Seco saying goodbye.  A strange feeling of intimacy.  She lean forward and she kisses him.  Total silence.  A real sense strangeness of those lips, those famous lips on his.  The

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I apologize for the 'surreal but nice' comment.  Disaster...

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it.  I thought the apricot and honey business was the real lowpoint. Suddenly there is a clicking of a key in the lock.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh my God.  My flatmate.  I'm sorry -- there's no excuse for him. Spike walks in.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hi. Spike walks past unsuspiciously and heads into the kitche

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: I'm just going to go into the kitchen to get some food -- and then I'm going to tell you a story that will make your balls shrink to the size of raisins. And leaves them in the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Probably best not tell anyone about this.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Right.  No one.  I mean, I'll tell myself sometimes but... don't worry -- I won't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Bye. And she leaves, with just a touch of William's hand.  Spi comes out of the kitchen, eating something white out of a styrofoam container with a spoon.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: There's something wrong with this yogurt.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It's not yogurt -- it's mayonnaise.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Well, there you go. (takes another big spoonful) On for a video fest tonight?  I've got some absolute classic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are off.  William and Spike on the couch, just light from the TV playing on their faces.  Cut to the TV screen.  There is Anna.  She is in a stylish Woody Allen modern romantic comedy, 'Gramercy Park,' in black and whi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna's character -- Woody Anna -- is walking around the g with her famous co-star, Michael.  They should be the per couple, but there is tension.  Anna is not happy.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Smile.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Smile.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I've got nothing to smile about.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Okay in about 7 seconds, I'm going to ask you to marry me. And after a couple of seconds -- wow -- she smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Imagine -- somewhere in the world there's a man who's allowed to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yes, she is fairly fabulous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day.  William and Martin quietly co-existing.  A ing customer enters.  Mr. Smith.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SMITH
dialogues.text: Do you have any books by Dickens?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No, we're a travel bookshop.  We only sell travel books.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SMITH
dialogues.text: Oh right.  How about that new John Grisham thriller?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No, that's a novel too.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SMITH
dialogues.text: Oh right.  Have you got a copy of 'Winnie the Pooh'? Pause.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Martin -- your customer.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Can I help you? William looks up.  At that moment the entire window is su taken up by the huge side of a bus, obscuring the light - entirely covered with a portrait of Anna -- from her new 'Helix.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William heads upstairs and pauses.  Spike coming down, we full body scuba diving gear.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them fixing a cup of tea in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Just incidentally -- why are you wearing that?

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Ahm -- combination of factors really. No clean clothes...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: There never will be, you know, unless you actually clean your clothes.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Right.  Vicious circle.  And then I was like rooting around in your things, and found this, and I thought -- cool. Kind of spacey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them on the rooftop terrace, passing the day. William is reading 'The bookseller.'  The terrace is smal the plants aren't great -- but it overlooks London in a r wonderful way.  Spike still in scuba gear, goggles on.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: There's something wrong with the goggles though...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No, they were prescription, so I could see all the fishes properly.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Groovy.  You should do more of this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: So -- any messages?

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Yeh, I wrote a couple down.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Two?  That's it?

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: You want me to write down all your messages? William closes his eyes in exasperation.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Who were the ones you didn't write down from?

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Ahm let's see -- ahm.  No.  Gone completely.  Oh no, wait.  There was -- one from your mum: she said don't forget lunch and her leg's hurting again.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Right.  No one else?

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Absolutely not. Spike leans back and relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Though if we're going for this obsessive writing-down-all-messages thing -- some American girl called Anna called a few days ago. William freezes -- then looks at Spike.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What did she say?

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Well, it was genuinely bizarre... she said, hi -- it's Anna -- and then she said, call me at the Ritz -- and then gave herself a completely different name.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Which was?

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Absolutely no idea.  Remembering one name's bad enough...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William on the phone.  We hear the formal man at the othe the phone.  And then intercut with him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: RITZ MAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: May I help you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Ahm, look this is a very odd situation.  I'm a friend of Anna Scott's -- and she rang me at home the day before yesterday -- and left a message saying she's staying with you...

dialogues.speaker: RITZ MAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, we don't have anyone of that name here, sir.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No, that's right -- I know that.  She said she's using another name -- but the problem is she left the message with my flatmate, which was a serious mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WILLIAM (cont'd) Imagine if you will the stupidest person you've ever met -- are you doing that...? Spike happens to be in the foreground of this shot.  He's ing a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: RITZ MAN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  I have him in my mind.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: And then double it -- and that is the -- what can I say -- git I'm living with and he cannot remember...

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Try 'Flintstone.'

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (to Spike) What?

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: I think she said her name was 'Flintstone.'

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Does 'Flintstone' mean anything to you?

dialogues.speaker: RITZ MAN
dialogues.text: I'll put you right through, sir. Flintstone is indeed the magic word.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh my God. He practices how to sound.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hello.  Hi.  Hi.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hi. We hear her voice -- don't see her.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (caught out) Oh hi.  It's William Thacker.  We, ahm I work in a bookshop.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You played it pretty cool here, waiting for three days to call.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No, I've never played anything cool in my entire life.  Spike, who I'll stab to death later, never gave me the message.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh -- Okay.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Perhaps I could drop round for tea or something?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yeh -- unfortunately, things are going to be pretty busy, but... okay, let's give it a try.  Four o'clock could be good.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Right.  Great. (he hangs up) Classic.  Classic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William jumps off a bus and walks toward the Ritz.  He ca small bunch of roses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He approaches the lifts.  At the lift, he pushes the butt the doors open.  As he is getting in, William is joined b man.  His name is Tarquin.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Which floor?

dialogues.speaker: TARQUIN
dialogues.text: Three. William pushes the button.  They wait for the doors to cl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lift lands.  William gets out.  So does Tarquin.  Roo 30-35 are to the left.  35-39 to the right.  William head So does Tarquin. William is puzzled.  He slows down as he approaches room does Tarquin.  William spots, so does Tarquin.  William p at the number.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Are you sure you...?

dialogues.speaker: TARQUIN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh.  Right. He knocks.  A bright, well-tailored American girl opens t

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Hello, I'm Karen.  Sorry -- things are running a bit late.  Here's the thing... She hands them a very slick, expensively produced press k with the poster picture of Anna, for the film 'Helix.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few seconds later -- they enter the main waiting room. are a number of journalists waiting for their audience.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: What did you think of the film?

dialogues.speaker: TARQUIN
dialogues.text: Marvellous.  'Close Encounters' meets 'Jean De Florette.'  Oscar- winning stuff. They both turn to William for his opinion.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I agree.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  I didn't get down what magazines you're from.

dialogues.speaker: TARQUIN
dialogues.text: 'Time Out.'

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Great.  And you...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (seeing it on a coffee table) 'Horse and Hound.'  The name's William Whacker.  I think she might be expecting me.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Okay -- take a seat.  I'll check. They sit down as Karen goes off.

dialogues.speaker: TARQUIN
dialogues.text: You've brought her flowers? William goes for the cover-up.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No -- they're... for my grandmother. She's in a hospital nearby.  Thought I'd kill two birds with one stone.

dialogues.speaker: TARQUIN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  Which hospital? Pause.  He's in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Do you mind me not saying -- it's a rather distressing disease and the name of the hospital rather gives it away.

dialogues.speaker: TARQUIN
dialogues.text: Oh sure.  Of course.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Mr. Thacker. Saved by the bell.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: You've got five minutes. He is shown in through big golden doors.  Karen stays out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There Anna is, framed in the window.  Glorious.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I brought these, but clearly... There are lots of other flowers in the room.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Oh no, ho -- these are great. A fair amount of tension.  These two people hardly know e other -- and the first and last time they met, they kisse

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Sorry about not ringing back.  The whole two-names concept was totally too much for my flatman's pea-sized intellect.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No, it's a stupid privacy thing.  I always choose a cartoon character -- last time out, I was Mrs. Bambi. At which moment Jeremy, Karen's boss, comes in.  A fairly authoritative fifty-year-old PR man consulting a list.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: Everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: And you are from 'Horse and Hound' magazine? William nods.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Is that so? William shrugs his shoulders.  Jeremy settles at a little in the corner and makes notes.  A pause.  William feels h act the part.  They sit in chairs opposite each other.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: So I'll just fire away, shall I? Anna nods.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Right.  Ahm... the film's great... and I just wondered -- whether you ever thought of having more... horses in it?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Ahm -- well -- we would have liked to -- but it was difficult, obviously, being set in space.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Obviously.  Very difficult. Jeremy leaves. William puts his head in his hands.  He was panic.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I'm sorry -- I arrived outside -- they thrust this thing into my hand -- I didn't know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No, it's my fault, I thought this would all be over by now.  I just wanted to sort of apologize for the kissing thing.  I seriously don't know what got in to me.  I just wanted to make sure you were fine about it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Absolutely fine about it. Re-enter Jeremy.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: Do remember that Miss Scott is also keen to talk about her next project, which is shooting later in the summer.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh yes -- excellent.  Ahm -- any horses in that one?  Or hounds, of course.  Our readers are equally intrigued by both species.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: It takes place on a submarine.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yes.  Right... But if there were horses, would you be riding them yourself or would you be getting a stunt horse person double sort of thing? Jeremy exits.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I'm just a complete moron.  Sorry. This is the sort of thing that happens in dreams -- not in real life.  Good dreams, obviously -- it's a dream to see you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: And what happens next in the dream? It's a challenge.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose in the dream dream scenario.  I just... ahm, change my personality, because you can do that in dreams, and  walk across and kiss the girl but you know it'll never happen. Pause.  Then they move towards each other when... Jeremy enters.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: Time's up, I'm afraid.  Sorry it was so short.  Did you get what you wanted?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Very nearly.

dialogues.speaker: JEREMY
dialogues.text: Maybe time for one last question?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Right. Jeremy goes out -- it's their last seconds.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Are you busy tonight?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes. They look at each other.  Jeremy enters, with another jou in tow.  Anna and William stand and shake hands formally.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Well, it was nice to meet you. Surreal but nice.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Thank you.  You are 'Horse and Hound's' favorite actress.  You and Black Beauty.  Tied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William exits fairly despondent and heads for the door. is in the corridor calling on his mobile phone.

dialogues.speaker: TARQUIN
dialogues.text: How was she?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Fabulous.

dialogues.speaker: TARQUIN
dialogues.text: Wait a minute -- she took your grandmother's flowers? William can't think his way out of this.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yes.  That's right.  Bitch. He turns to go, but is accosted by Karen.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: If you'd like to come with me we can rush you through the others.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: The others?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Mr. Thacker's from 'Horse and Hound.' A forty-year-old actor with great presence warmly shakes William's hand.

dialogues.speaker: MALE LEAD
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you.  Did you like the film?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Ah... yes, enormously.

dialogues.speaker: MALE LEAD
dialogues.text: Well, fire away.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Right, right.  Ahm -- did you enjoy making the film?

dialogues.speaker: MALE LEAD
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Any bit in particular?

dialogues.speaker: MALE LEAD
dialogues.text: Well, you tell me which bit you liked most -- and I'll tell you if I enjoyed making it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Ahm right, right, I liked the bit in space very much.  Did you enjoy making  that bit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same room same seat, minutes later, with a monolingual fo actor and an interpreter.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Did you identify with the character you were playing?

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Te identicaste con el personaje que interpretabas?

dialogues.speaker: FOREIGN ACTOR
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Ah.  Why not?

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Por que no?

dialogues.speaker: FOREIGN ACTOR
dialogues.text: Porque es un robot carnivoro psicopata.

dialogues.speaker: INTERPRETER
dialogues.text: Because he is playing a psychopathic flesh-eating robot.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Classic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now William is sitting opposite an eleven-year-old Am girl.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Is this your first film?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: No -- it's my 22nd.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Of course it is.  Any favourite among the 22?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Working with Leonardo.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Da Vinci?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Di Caprio.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Of course.  And is he your favourite Italian film director?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William emerges traumatized into the corridor.  It is ful camera crews.  And there is Karen.

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Mr. Thacker?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (so weary) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: KAREN
dialogues.text: Have you got a moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They knock on her door.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Come in. William enters.  A certain nervousness.  They are alone a

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Ahm.  That thing I was doing tonight -- I'm not doing it any more.  I told them I had to spend the evening with Britain's premier equestrian journalist.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh well, great.  Perfect.  Oh no -- shittity brickitty -- it's my sister's birthday -- shit -- we're meant to be having dinner.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Okay -- fine.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: But no, I'm sure I can get out of it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No, I mean, if it's fine with you, I'll, you know, be your date.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You'll be my date at my little sister's birthday party?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: If that's all right.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I'm sure it's all right.  My friend Max is cooking and he's acknowledged to be the worst cook in the world, but you know, you could hide the food in your handbag or something.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bella and Max are in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: He's bringing a girl?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Miracles do happen.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Does the girl have a name?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: He wouldn't say.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Christ, what is going on in there? The oven seems to be smoking a little.  Then the bell rin MAX (cont'd) Oh God. It's bad timing.  Max shoots out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max heads for the door impatiently.  He opens it and turn without looking at William and Anna standing there.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Come on in.  Vague food crisis. William and Anna move along the corridor to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bella is there.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Hiya -- sorry -- the guinea fowl is proving more complicated than expected.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: He's cooking guinea fowl?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Don't even ask.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Hi.  Good Lord -- you're the spitting image of...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Bella -- this is Anna.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Right. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Okay.  Crisis over. He rises from his stove position.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Max.  This is Anna.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Hello, Anna ahm... (He recognizes her -- the word just falls out) Scott -- have some wine.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Thank you. Door bell goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max opens the door -- it is Honey.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Hi. She does a little pose, having worn a real party dress.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Yes, Happy Birthday. They head back along the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Look, your brother has brought this girl, and ahm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: HONEY
dialogues.text: Hi guys. (sees Anna) Oh holy fuck.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hun -- this is Anna.  Anna -- this is Honey -- she's my baby sitter.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Hiya.

dialogues.speaker: HONEY
dialogues.text: Oh God this is one of those key moments in life, when it's possible you can be really, genuinely cool -- and I'm going to fail a hundred percent.  I absolutely and totally and utterly adore you and I think you're the most beautiful woman in the world and more importantly I genuinely believe and have believed for some time now that we can be best friends.  What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Ahm... I think that sounds -- you know -- lucky me.  Happy Birthday. She hands her a present.

dialogues.speaker: HONEY
dialogues.text: Oh my God.  You gave me a present. We're best friends already.  Marry Will -- he's a really nice guy and then we can be sisters.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I'll think about it. The front door bell goes.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: That'll be Bernie. He heads out into the corridor to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Hello, Bernie.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I'm so late.  Bollocksed up at work again, I fear.  Millions down the drain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the room.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Bernie -- this is Anna.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Hello, Anna.  Delighted to meet you. Doesn't recognize her -- turns to Honey.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Honey Bunny -- happy birthday to you. (hands her a present) It's a hat.  You don't have to wear it or anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A minute or two later -- they are standing, drinking wine dinner.  Bernie with Anna on their own -- William helping the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: You haven't slept with her, have you?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: That is a cheap question and the answer is, of course, no comment.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: 'No comment' means 'yes.'

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No, it doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Do you ever masturbate?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Definitely no comment.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: You see -- it means 'yes.' Then on to Bernie's conversation.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: So tell me Anna -- what do you do?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I'm an actress.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Splendid.  I'm actually in the stock- market, so not really similar fields, though I have done some amateur stuff -- P.G. Wodehouse, you know -- farce, all that.  'Ooh -- careful there, vicar.'  Always imagined it's a pretty tough job, though, acting. I mean the wages are a scandal, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Well, they can be.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: I see friends from university -- clever chaps -- been in the business longer than you -- they're scraping by on seven, eight thousand a year. It's no life.  What sort of acting do you do?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Films mainly.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Oh splendid.  Well done.  How's the pay in movies?  I mean, last film you did, what did you get paid?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Fifteen million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Right.  Right.  So that's... fairly good.  On the high side... have you tried the nuts?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Right -- I think we're ready. They all move towards the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (to Bella) I wonder if you could tell me where the...?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Oh, it's just down the corridor on the right.

dialogues.speaker: HONEY
dialogues.text: I'll show you. A moment's silence as they leave -- then in a split secon others all turn to William.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Quickly, quickly -- talk very quickly what are you doing here with Anna Scott?

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Anna Scott?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: The movie star?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Oh God.  Oh God.  Oh Goddy God. The horror of his remembered conversation slowly unfolds. Honey re-enters.

dialogues.speaker: HONEY
dialogues.text: I don't believe it.  I walked into the loo with her.  I was still talking when she started unbuttoning her jeans... She had to ask me to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little later.  They are sat at dinner.  Bella next to A

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: What do you think of the guinea fowl?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (whispering) I'm a vegetarian.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Oh God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving on through the evening -- they are very relaxed, a eat dinner.  A few seconds watching the evening going wel is taking this in -- real friends -- relaxed -- easy, tea And there's a cake.  Honey wears Bernie's unsuitable hat. watches William laughing at something and then putting hi in his hands with mock shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee time.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Having you here, Anna, firmly establishes what I've long suspected, that we really are the most desperate hot of under-achievers.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Shame!

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I'm not saying it's a bad thing, in fact, I think it's something we should take pride in.  I'm going to give the last brownie as a prize to the saddest act here. A little pause.  Then William turns to Bernie.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Bernie.

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Well, obviously it's me, isn't it -- I work in the City in a job I don't understand and everyone keeps getting promoted above me.  I haven't had a girlfriends since... puberty and, well, the long and short of it is, nobody fancies me, and if these cheeks get any chubbier, they never will.

dialogues.speaker: HONEY
dialogues.text: Nonsense.  I fancy you.  Or I did before you got so far.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: You see -- and unless I'm much mistaken, your job still pays you rather a lot of money, while Honey here, she earns nothing flogging her guts out at London's seediest record store.

dialogues.speaker: HONEY
dialogues.text: Yes.  And I don't have hair -- I've got feathers, and I've got funny goggly eyes, and I'm attracted to cruel men and ... no one'll ever marry me because my boosies have actually started shrinking.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: You see -- incredibly sad.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: On the other hand, her best friend is Anna Scott.

dialogues.speaker: HONEY
dialogues.text: That's true, I can't deny it.  She needs me, what can I say?

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: And most of her limbs work.  Whereas I'm stuck in its thing day and night, in a house full of ramps.  And to add insult to serious injury -- I've totally given up smoking, my favourite thing, and the truth is... we can't have a baby. Dead silence.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Bella. Bella shrugs her shoulders.  Bernie is totally grief-stru

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: No.  Not true...

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: C'est la vie... We're lucky in lots of ways, but... Surely it's worth a brownie. William reaches for her hand.  Max breaks the sombre mood

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know.  Look at William.  Very unsuccessful professionally.  Divorced.  Used to be handsome, now kind of squidgy around the edges -- and absolutely certain never to hear from Anna again after she's heard that his nickname at school was Floppy. They all laugh.  Anna smiles across at William.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: So I get the brownie?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I think you do, yes.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.  What about me?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?  You think you deserve the brownie?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Well... a shot at it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You'll have to prove it.  This is a great brownie and I'm going to fight for it.  State your claim.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Well, I've been on a diet since I was nineteen, which means basically I've been hungry for a decade.  I've had a sequence of not nice boyfriends -- one of whom hit me: and every time my heart gets broken it gets splashed across the newspapers as entertainment. Meantime, it cost millions to get me looking like this...

dialogues.speaker: HONEY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Really -- and one day, not long from now... While she says this, quiet settles around the table.  The is -- she sort of means it and is opening up to them.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: ... my looks will go, they'll find out I can't act and I'll become a sad middle-aged woman who looks a bit like someone who was famous for a while. Silence... they all look at her... then.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Nah!!!  Nice try, gorgeous -- but you don't fool anyone. The mood is instantly broken.  They all laugh.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Pathetic effort to hog the brownie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna and William are leaving.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: That was such a great evening.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I'm delighted. He holds out his hand to shake.  She kisses him on the ch He stumbles back with joy.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: And may I say that's a gorgeous tie.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Now you're lying.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You're right.  I told you I was bad at acting. Max loves this.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (to Bella) Lovely to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: And you.  I'll wait till you've gone before I tell him you're a vegetarian.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Night, night, Honey.

dialogues.speaker: HONEY
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry about the loo thing. I meant to leave but I just... look, ring me if you need someone to go shopping with.  I know lots of nice, cheap places... not that money necessarily... (gives up) nice to meet you. And Honey gives her a huge hug.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You too -- from now on you are my style guru. Anna and William head out... Bernie tries to save some di

dialogues.speaker: BERNIE
dialogues.text: Love your work. They move to the door and wave goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William and Anna step outside.  From inside they hear a m and hysterical scream of the friends letting out their tr feelings.  William is a little embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Sorry -- they always do that when I leave the house. The house is in Lansdowne Road, on the edge of Notting Hi They walk for a moment.  A bit of silence.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Floppy, huh?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It's the hair!  It's to do with the hair.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Why is she in a wheelchair?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It was an accident -- about eighteen months ago.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: And the pregnancy thing -- is that to do with the accident?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You know, I'm not sure.  I don't think they'd tried for kids before, as fate would have it. They walk in silence for a moment.  Then...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Would you like to come... my house is just...? She smiles and shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Too complicated.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: That's fine.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Busy tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I thought you were leaving.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little later in the walk.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What's in there? They are now walking by a five foot railing, with foliage behind it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Gardens.  All these streets round here have these mysterious communal gardens in the middle of them. They're like little villages.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Let's go in.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Ah no -- that's the point -- they're private villages -- only the people who live round the edges are allowed in.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You abide by rules like that?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Ahm... Her look makes it clear that she is waiting with interest the answer to this.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Heck no -- other people do -- but not me -- I just do what I want. He rattles the gate, then starts his climb -- but doesn't make it, and falls back onto the pavement...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (casually) Whoopsidaisies.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes, you did.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No, I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You said 'whoopsidaisies.' Tiny pause.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I don't think so.  No one has said 'whoopsidaisies,' do they -- I mean unless they're...

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: There's no 'unless.'  No one has said "whoopsidaisies" for fifty years and even then it was only little girls with blonde ringlets.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Exactly.  Here we go again. He fails, and unfortunately, spontaneously...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Whoopsidaisies. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It's a disease I've got -- it's a clinical thing.  I'm taking pills and having injections -- it won't last long.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Step aside. She starts to climb.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Actually be careful Anna -- it's harder than it looks... But she's already almost over.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh no it's not -- it's easy. A few seconds later.  Anna jumps down into the garden.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Come on, Flops. William clambers over with terrible difficulty, dusts him off, and heads towards where she stands.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Now seriously -- what in the world in this garden could make that ordeal worthwhile? She leans forward -- and, for the firs time since the fir time -- she kisses him.  This time a proper kiss.  A tiny

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Nice garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk around the garden.  It's a moonlit dream.  We s the lights of the houses that surround the garden.  They across a single, simple wooden bench.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: 'For June, who loved this garden -- from Joseph who always sat beside her.' We cut in and see an inscription carved into the wood.  S doesn't read the dates, carved below -- 'June Wetherby, 1 - 1992.'  She is slightly chocked by it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Some people do spend their whole lives together. He nods.  They are standing on either side of the bench, looking at each other.  The camera glides away from them, into the night sky, leaving them alone in the garden.  Mu plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William in a towel rushes downstairs, having just had a s He shoots past Spike.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Bollocks, bollocks, bollocks.  Have you seen my glasses?

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: No, 'fraid not.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Bollocks. (still searching -- with no help from Spike) This happens every time I go to the cinema.  Average day, my glasses are everywhere -- everywhere I look, glasses.  But the moment I need them they disappear.  It's one of life's real cruelties.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: That's compared to, like, earthquakes in the Far East or testicular cancer?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh shit, is that the time?  I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sprints downstairs, now fully dressed.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (not meaning it) Thanks for your help on the glasses thing.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: (sincerely) You're welcome.  Did you find them?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mid-film.  We move across the audience.  And there is in middle of it, we see Anna, watching the screen, and next her, William, watching the film keenly, through his scuba diving goggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very smart Japanese restaurant.  We see Anna and Willia sitting, near the end of their meal.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: So who left who?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: She left me.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: She saw through me.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Uh-oh.  That's not good. We've been aware of the conversation at a nearby table -- now we can hear it.  Two slightly rowdy men.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: No - No- No!  Give me Anna Scott any day. William and Anna look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: GERALD
dialogues.text: I didn't like that last film of hers. Fast asleep from the moment the lights went down. Again -- Anna reacts.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Don't really care what the films are like.  Any film with her in it -- fine by me.

dialogues.speaker: GERALD
dialogues.text: No -- not my type at all really.  I prefer that other one -- blonde -- sweet looking -- has an orgasm every time you take her out for a cup of coffee. Anna mouths 'Meg Ryan.'

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Meg Ryan. William and Anna smile -- they're enjoying it.

dialogues.speaker: GERALD
dialogues.text: Drug-induced, I hear -- I believe she's actually in rehab as we speak.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Whatever, she's so clearly up for it. Anna's twinkle fades.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: You know -- some girls, they're all 'stay away chum' but Anna, she's absolutely gagging for it.  Do you know that in over fifty percent of languages the word for "actress" is the same as the word for "prostitute." This is horrible.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: And Anna is your definitive actress -- someone really filthy you can just flip over...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Right, that's it. He gets up and goes round the corner to the men.  There a fact four of them, the two meeker men, Gavin and Harry, h on the other guys' witty words.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to disturb you guys but --

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, yes, I wish I hadn't overheard your conversation -- but I did and I just think, you know... He's not a very convincing or frightening figure.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: ...the person you're talking about is a real person and I think she probably deserves a little bit more consideration, rather than having jerks like you drooling over her...

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Oh sod off, mate.  What are you, her dad? Anna suddenly appears at his side and whips him away with being recognized.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No, that's fine.  I love that you tried... time was I'd have done the same. They walk on and then...

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: In fact -- give me a second. And she walks straight back to their table.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Oh my God...

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about my friend -- he's very sensitive.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: No, look, I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Please, please -- let's just leave it there.  I'm sure you meant no harm, and I'm sure it was just friendly banter and I'm sure you dicks are all the size of peanuts.  A perfect match for the size of your brains.  Enjoy your meal.  The tuna's really good. And she walks away.  Gerald turns to Lawrence.

dialogues.speaker: GERALD
dialogues.text: You prick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are walking.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have done that.  I shouldn't have done that.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No, you were brilliant

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I'm rash and I'm stupid and what am I doing with you?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I don't know, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I don't know either. They have arrived at the end of the arcade.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Here we are. (pause) Do you want to come up?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (he hoes) There seem to be lots of reasons why I shouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: There are lots of reasons.  Do you want to come up? His look says yes.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Give me five minutes. He watches her go -- and stands in the street.  Music pla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William coming along the hotel corridor.  He knocks on th door.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Hiya. There's something slightly awry.  He doesn't notice.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hi. He kisses her gently on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: To be able to do that is such a wonderful thing.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (pause) You've got to go.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Because my boyfriend, who I thought was in America, is in fact in the next room.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Your boyfriend? He is duly shocked.  She's trying to be calm.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: JEFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Who is it? Jeff drifts into view behind.  He is a very famous film s looks the part -- well built, very handsome.  Unshaven, h magic charm, whatever he says.  Over a t-shirt, he wears shirt, which he unbuttons as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Ahm... room service.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: How you doing?  I thought you guys all wore those penguin coats.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, yes -- usually -- I'd just changed to go home -- but I thought I'd just deal with this final call.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Oh great.  Could you do me a favour and try to get us some really cold water up here?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I'll see what I can do.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Still, not sparkling.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Absolutely.  Ice cold still water.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Unless it's illegal in the UK to serve liquids below room temperature: I don't want you going to jail just to satisfy my whims...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No, I'm sure it'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: And maybe you could just adios the dishes and empty the trash.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Right. And he does just that.  Scoops up the two used plates and to the bin.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Really -- don't do that -- I'm sure this is not his job.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  Is this a problem?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Ah -- no.  It's fine.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Ahm... Bernie. Jeff slips him a fiver.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Thank you, Bernie. (to Anna) Hey -- nice surprise, or nasty surprise?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Nice surprise. He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Liar. (to William) She hates surprises.  What are you ordering?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I haven't decided.

dialogues.speaker: JEFF
dialogues.text: Well, don't over-do it.  I don't want people saying, 'There goes that famous actor with the big, fat girlfriend." He wanders off taking off his t-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I better leave. Anna just nods.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: -- this is a fairly strange reality to be faced with.  To be honest, I don't realize...

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... I don't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I think goodbye is traditional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William walks down the arcade outside the hotel.  He is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William sits alone on a bus.  We see him through the side window.  As it drives away, we see that the whole back of bus is taken up with a huge picture of Anna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets into his room and sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Space Anna, in the very hi-tech environment and a serious moods, fastens the last clasps on her uniform.  She takes helmet type thing, and places it on her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut round to the Coronet cinema where this film is showin It's not full.  The camera moves and finds, sitting on hi own...William.  Just watching.  We see a momentous flash light from the screen explode, reflected in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William is looking out the window, lost in thought.  Spik enters.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Come on -- open up -- this is me -- Spikey -- I'm in contact with some quite important spiritual vibrations. What's wrong? Spike settles on the arm of a chair.  William decides to up a bit...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, okay.  There's this girl...

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Aha!  I'd been getting a female vibe. Good.  Speak on, dear friend.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: She's someone I just can't -- someone who... self-evidently can't be mine -- and it's as if I've taken love-heroin -- and now I can't even have it again. I've opened Pandora's box.  And there's trouble inside. Spike nods thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Yeh.  Yeh... tricky... tricky... I knew a girl at school called Pandora ... never got to see her box though. He roars with laughter.  William smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Thanks.  Yes -- very helpful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only two tables are being used.  William and his friends on their first course.  Bernie reads an "Evening Standard with a picture of Anna and Jeff at Heathrow Airport.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: You didn't know she had a boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No -- did you? Their looks make it obvious that everyone did.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Bloody hell, I can't believe it -- my whole life ruined because I don't read 'Hello' magazine.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Let's face facts.  This was always a no-go situation.  Anna's a goddess and you know what happens to mortals who get involved with the gods.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Buggered?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Every time.  But don't despair -- I think I have the solution to your problems.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Really? They all look to him for wise words.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Her name is Tessa and she works in the contracts department.  The hair, I admit, is unfashionable frizzy -- but she's as bright as a button and kisses like a nymphomaniac on death row.  Apparently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kitchen.  William is looking uneasy.  A doorbell ring

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Now -- try. William nods.  Max heads off to the door.  We stay with W -- and just hear the door open and a voice come down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: TESSA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I got completely lost -- it's real difficult, isn't it?  Everything's got the word 'Kensington' in it -- Kensington Park Road, Kensington Gardens, Kensington bloody Park Gardens... They reach the kitchen.  Tessa is a lush girl with huge h

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Tessa -- this is Bella my wife.

dialogues.speaker: TESSA
dialogues.text: Oh hello, you're in a wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: And this is William.

dialogues.speaker: TESSA
dialogues.text: Hello William.  Max has told me everything about you.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (frightened) Has he?

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Wine?

dialogues.speaker: TESSA
dialogues.text: Oh yes please.  Come on, Willie, let's get sloshed. She turns to take the wine and William has a split second a message of panic to Bella.  She agrees -- it's bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max walks over to the table.  Honey, Bella, William and a girl.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Keziah -- some woodcock?

dialogues.speaker: KEZIAH
dialogues.text: No, thank you  -- I'm a fruitarian.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: I don't realize that. It is left to William, who has been set up here, to fill pause.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: And ahm -- what's a fruitarian exactly?

dialogues.speaker: KEZIAH
dialogues.text: We believe that fruits and vegetables have feelings so we think cooking is cruel.  We only eat things that have actually fallen from the tree or bush -- that are, in fact, dead already.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Right.  Right.  Interesting stuff. (pause) So these carrots...

dialogues.speaker: KEZIAH
dialogues.text: Have been murdered, yes.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Murdered?  Poor carrots.  How beastly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time for coffee and chocolates.  Beside William sits the perfect girl.  She is Rosie, quite young, smartly dressed open-hearted.  It is just Max and William and Bella and h

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Delicious coffee.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Thank you.  I'm sorry about the lamb.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: No -- I thought it was really, you know, interesting.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Interesting means inedible.

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Really inedible -- yes that's right. They all laugh.  It's going very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William is with Rosie by the door -- just about to say go

dialogues.speaker: ROSIE
dialogues.text: Maybe we'll meet again some time.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yes.  That would be... great. She kisses him gently on the cheek.  He opens the door -- walks out.  He shuts the door quietly and heads back into living room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max and Bella wait excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: She's perfect, perfect.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: And? William makes a gentle, exasperated gesture, then...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I think you have forgotten... (he looks at them) what an unusual situation you have here -- to find someone you actually love, who'll love you -- the chances are... always miniscule.  Look at me -- not counting the American -- I've only loved two girls in my whole life, both total disasters.

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: That's not fair.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No really, one of them marries me and then leaves me quicker than you can say Indiana Jones -- and the other, who seriously ought to have known better, casually marries my best friend.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: (pause) Still loves you though.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: In a depressingly asexual way.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: (pause) I never fancied you much actually... They all roar with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: I mean I loved you -- you were terribly funny.  But all that kissing my ears...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh no -- this is just getting worse. I am going to find myself, 30 years from now, still on this couch.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA
dialogues.text: Do you want to stay?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Why not -- all that awaits me at home is a masturbating Welshman. Music starts to play to take us through these silent scen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max lifts Bella off her couch and carries her upstairs. Mix through -- William sits on the couch downstairs -- ey open -- thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning.  Max, all in his suit for the city... Bella kiss goodbye.  William sees this from the kitchen.  She is als dressed for work -- and moves back into the kitchen to pa briefcase with law books from the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William emerges from the house, a little ruffled from a n away from home, a heads off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William walks past the newsagent, heading for home.  We s though he doesn't, a rack of tabloid papers, all of which to have very grainy, grabbed pictures of Anna on their fr page.  Headlines --'Anna Stunna'-- 'It's Definitely Her!' and 'Scott of Pantartica.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William is shaving.  The bell goes.  He heads out to answ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William arrives at the door and opens it.  There stands a glassed Anna.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Hi.  Can I come in?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Come in. She moves inside.  Her hair is a mess -- her eyes are tir Nothing idealized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: They were taken years ago -- I know it was... well, I was poor and it happens a lot -- that's not an excuse -- but to make things worse, it now appears someone was filming me as well.  So what was a stupid photo- shoot now looks like a porno film. And well... the pictures have been solid and they're everywhere. William shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I don't know where to go.  The hotel is surrounded.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: This is the place.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Thank you.  I'm just in London for two days -- but, with your papers, it's the worse place to be. She's very shaken.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: These are such horrible pictures. They're so grainy... they make me look like...

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Don't think about it.  We'll sort it out.  Now what would you like -- tea ... bath...?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: A bath would be great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spike enters through the front door.  William doesn't hea Spike is reading newspapers with the Anna pictures in it.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Christ alive... brilliant... fantastic .... magnificent... He heads up the stairs.  Opens the bathroom door, walks i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spike heads for the toilet -- undoes his zip...

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You must be Spike. She's in the bath.  Spike turns in shock -- and sidles ou bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spike calms himself down.  He then opens the bathroom doo again -- and looks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is still lying low in the bath.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Just checking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spike comes back out into the corridor.  Looks to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: SPIKE
dialogues.text: Thank you, God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William and Anna at the kitchen table, eating toast, drin tea.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I'm really sorry about last time.  He just flew in -- I had no idea -- in fact, I had no idea if he'd ever fly in again.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No, that's fine.  It's not often one has the opportunity to adios the plates of a major Hollywood star.  It was a thrill for me. (she smiles.  Pause) How is he?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I don't know.  It got to the point where I couldn't remember any of the reasons I loved him.  And you... and love?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well, there's a question -- without an interesting answer.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I have thought about you.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Oh no no -- no. He doesn't think she has to talk about this.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Just anytime I've tried to keep things normal with anyone normal -- it's been a disaster.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I appreciate that absolutely. (changing subject tactfully) Is that the film you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes -- start in L.A. on Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Would you like me to take you through your lines?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Would you?  It's all talk, talk, talk.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Hand it over.  Basic plot?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I'm a difficult but brilliant junior officer who in about twenty minutes will save the world from nuclear disaster.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Well done you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little later.  They're in the thick of the script.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: 'Message from command.  Would you like them to send in the HKs?'

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: 'No, turn over 4 TRS's and tell them we need radar feedback before the KFT's return at 19 hundred -- then inform the Pentagon that we'll be needing black star cover from ten hundred through 12.15' -- and don't you dare say one word about how many mistakes I made in that speech or I'll pelt you with olives.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
